PermissionInformation.Comment: Copyright permission not needed; image created by T Winslow

ContentDescriptions.ContentDescription: Blood cell development; drawing shows the steps a blood stem cell goes through to become a red blood cell, platelet, or white blood cell. A myeloid stem cell becomes a red blood cell, a platelet, or a myeloblast, which then becomes a granulocyte (the types of granulocytes are eosinophils, basophils, and neutrophils). A lymphoid stem cell becomes a lymphoblast and then becomes a B-lymphocyte, T-lymphocyte, or natural killer cell.

Blood cell development; drawing shows the steps a blood stem cell goes through to become a red blood cell, platelet, or white blood cell. A myeloid stem cell becomes a red blood cell, a platelet, or a myeloblast, which then becomes a granulocyte (the types of granulocytes are eosinophils, basophils, and neutrophils). A lymphoid stem cell becomes a lymphoblast and then becomes a B-lymphocyte, T-lymphocyte, or natural killer cell.

Captions.MediaCaption: Blood cell development. A blood stem cell goes through several steps to become a red blood cell, platelet, or white blood cell.
Blood cell development. A blood stem cell goes through several steps to become a red blood cell, platelet, or white blood cell.

MediaContent.Comment: The following sentence will be added as the last sentence when making the media link in each summary because it will vary depending on the type of cancer: "(type of cancer) is cancer of the (type of cell)." Example: "Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) is cancer of the lymphoblasts."

ProcessingStatus.ProcessingStatusValue: Approved by expert reviewer with changes
ProcessingStatus.Comment: Change labels from Pre-myeloid cell and Pre-lymphoid cell to Myeloid stem cell and Lymphoid stem cell, respectively. Move the Myeloblast cell and label to the right and draw arrows from the Myeloid stem cell to the Myeloblast and then to the Granulocytes. Bascially, the only cell types that come from the myeloblast are the granulocytes. Draw longer arrows directly from the Myeloid stem cell to the Red blood cells and the Platelets.
